Lesson 3: Guidelines for Developmentally Appropriate Practice in Action

Based on the DAP principles outlined in Lesson 2, the following guidelines address decisions that early childhood professionals make in six key and interrelated areas of practice.

Summary of Early Childhood Professional Guidelines
Guideline:
Effective, early childhood professionals... 		Rationale:
In order to... 		Practice:
By utilizing strategies such as...
1. Create a Caring Community of Learners

Image by freepik under Freepik

Help all children feel accepted and to encourage a positive atmosphere
  • Being warm and caring
  • Getting to know each child
  • Encouraging children's friendships
  • Creating opportunities for students to share their interests and parts of their culture
  • Ensuring all children, including dual language learners and those with delays or disabilities can participate and feel successful in all classroom activities
2. Engage in Community Relationships

Image by bearfotos under Freepik

Create a high quality classroom where families are seen as partners that can support the curriculum and help educators learn more about the children
  • Welcoming families in the classroom throughout the year
  • Inviting families to support children's learning and celebrate their work
  • Using families' knowledge to better understand the students
  • Listening to families' concerns and goals and working together to address any issues that come up
  • Valuing families as a resource that supports the curriculum, for example, if your child's class is learning about plants, the teacher might ask family members who garden to share what they know with students
  • Giving families regular reports about children's progress and what they're studying
  • Communicating effectively with everyone in the community
3. Observe and Assess Children’s Development

Image by freepik under Freepik

  • Evaluate students throughout the learning process and school year to plan and adapt the curriculum to meet each child's needs
  • Monitor children's progress to evaluate and improve their teaching
  • Measure the children's and school's progress toward state learning standards and screen students for possible delays, disabilities, or special learning needs
  • Record children's learning as it happens, when possible, then use this information to shape their teaching
  • Regularly check each child's progress toward goals
  • Use observations, in-class assessments, and discussions with families and specialists to make decisions about instruction, resources, individual goals, instruction, and how to group children for learning
4. Teach to Enhance Development and Learning

Image by rawpixel.com under Freepik

Create environments and schedules that allow children to actively participate with learning materials and with each other, which is how they learn best
  • Encouraging children's efforts and giving personal feedback to support continued learning and bolster self-confidence
  • Designing organized spaces that invite children to explore, choose activities, and interact with others
  • Choosing materials and activities that inspire children's curiosity for learning and help make a subject more real to them
  • Using strategies that support deeper levels of understanding, like asking children questions to help them dig into what they're studying and encouraging them to come up with different solutions
  • Offering children many opportunities to practice social skills during group work and whole class discussions
5. Plan an engaging curriculum

Image by freepik under Freepik

Achieve important goals by outlining what students should know and be able to do in all areas of learning and what materials, strategies, and approaches teachers can use to help children learn
  • Creating learning activities that respect children's experiences
  • Including books and other resources in the room that feature characters of different races, ages, abilities, genders, and cultures
  • Developing lessons that connect subjects, like social studies and language arts
  • Introducing long-term projects that require students to use skills from different subject areas
6. Demonstrate Professionalism

Image by freepik under Freepik

Continue building an established, strong profession working toward the mutual goal to effectively promote all young children’s development and learning across all settings
  • Using the guidelines of the profession, including NAEYC’s foundational documents, in order to conduct themselves as members of the profession and serve as advocates for young children, their families, and the profession itself
  • Knowing and applying the NAEYC Code of Ethical Conduct to resolve issues encountered in early childhood care
  • Practicing culturally sensitive communication with families
  • Engaging in collaborative and respectful relationships with coworkers
  • Respecting confidentiality of information
  • Maintaining inclusive environments that support the needs of each child

Resource: For more information, review NAEYC’s Professional Standards and Competencies for Early Childhood Educators and other recommendations for early childhood educators in the Advancing Equity in Early Childhood Education position statement.

Assessment

Instructions: Use the dropdown menus below to select a DAP guideline that finishes each statement and answer the reflection questions.

Reflection is a key skill for applying the content you are learning. Consider posting these take-aways in a place that is visible. Add the steps you chose for working on a guideline to your calendar, planner or to-do list.

If you’d like to work on a paper copy of your reflection, use this printable version of the reflection questions.
